facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal reversed AAC order and restored ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decisions of the A.A.C., the Department took up the matter in appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. The Tribunal reversed the order of the A.A.C. and restored that of the I.T.O.

facts.text: Tribunal concluded selling agency agreement was make-believe arrangement to minimise tax liability, not genuine.

anchor.surface_text: It came to the companyclusion that the so called selling agency agreement between the assessee firm and the selling agency firm was only a make-believe arrangement. It was merely a device to minimise the tax liability of the assessee firm and it was number a genuine business arrangement.

facts.text: Selling agency firm had partners: Shiva Kumari Bagaria (wife of Madanlal, 1/3rd share), Triveni Devi Bagaria (wife of Bajranglal, 1/9th), Kanti Prasad Bagaria (son of Bajranglal, 1/9th), Nandlal Bagaria (minor son of Bajranglal, 1/9th), Banarshi Devi Bagaria (wife of Sohanlal, 1/9th), Shyamsunder Bagaria (minor son of Sohanlal, 1/6th).

anchor.surface_text: The selling agency firm had four major partners. Two minors were also entitled to share in the benefits of that partnership. One of the major partner was Shiva Kumari Bagaria wife of Madan Lal Bagaria, one of the partners in the assessee firm. She had a 1/3rd share in the profits of the selling agency firm. Another partner of that firm was Triveni Devi Bagaria wife of Bajranglal Bagaria, a partner in the assessee firm. She had 1/9th share in the profits of the selling agency firm. Bajianglals major son Kanti Prasad Bagaria was another partner in the selling agency firm. He had 1/9th share in the profits of that firm. Nandlal Bagaria, the minor son of Bajranglal Bagaria was en- titled to get 1/9th share in the profits of the selling agency firm. In effect the wife and the children of Bajranglal were entitled to 1/3rd share in the profits of the selling agency firm. Another partner of the selling agency firm was Banarshi Devi Bagaria, 15-L348Sup.C.I./73 wife of Sohan Lai Bagaria, one of the partners in the assessee firm. She had 1/9th share in the, profits of the selling agency firm. Shyamsunder Bagaria, minor son of Sohanlal was entitled to get1/6th share in the profits of the selling agency firm.

facts.text: Wife and children of Bajranglal entitled to 1/3rd share in selling agency firm.

anchor.surface_text: In effect the wife and the children of Bajranglal were entitled to 1/3rd share in the profits of the selling agency firm. Another partner of the selling agency firm was Banarshi Devi Bagaria,

facts.text: Wife and son of Sohanlal entitled to 1/3rd share in selling agency firm.

anchor.surface_text: This shows that the wife and son of Sohanlal were entitled to 1/3rd share in the profits of the selling agency firm. From these facts, the Tirbunal inferred that the selling agency firm is numberhing but another manifestation of the, assessee firm.

anchor.surface_text: It came into existence for the first time on April 13, 1962. The partnership agreement clearly shows that the partnership came into existence only on April 13, 1962. This discrepancy between the two documents was emphasised by the Tribunal

arguments.claim: Tax avoidance by arranging affairs permissible unless device makes assessee's income appear as another's

anchor.surface_text: Avoidance of tax liability by so arranging commercial affairs that charge of tax is distributed is not prohibited. A tax payer may resort to a device to divert the income before it accrues or arises to him. Effectiveness of the device depends not upon considerations of morality but on the operation of the Income-tax Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: But here Tribunal found it was such impermissible device

arguments.claim: Tribunal justified in not stating case under S.256(1); High Court in not calling under S.256(2)

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, we are of opinion that the Tribunal was justified in not stating a case for the opinion of the High Court under s. 256 (1) of the Act and the High Court was justified in not calling for a statement of case under sub-s. (2) of s. 256.

holdings.text: No question of law arose from the order of the Tribunal which required the Tribunal to state the case for the opinion of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: special leave. The question for decision is whether any question of law arose from the order of the Tribunal which required the Tribunal to state the case for the opinion of the High Court. The assessee is a registered firm of three partners, Madanlal Bagaria, Bajranglal Bagaria and Sohanlal Bagaria, each having a 1/3rd share in the partnership.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's findings on sham nature of arrangement are findings of fact, not vitiated by misconstruction of documents or ignoring evidence; no perversity.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was justified in not stating a case for the opinion of the High Court under s. 256(1) of the Act and the High Court was justified in not calling for a statement of case under sub-s. (2) of s. 256.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, we are of opinion that the Tribunal was justified in not stating a case for the opinion of the High Court under s. 256 (1) of the Act and the High Court was justified in not calling for a statement of case under sub-s. (2) of s. 256.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No substantial question of law as Tribunal findings of fact upheld; applies test for perversity and interference under reference provisions.

holdings.text: The mere existence of an agreement and payment of commission does not bind the Income-tax Officer to allow deduction under s. 37; ITO may scrutinize relevant factors to determine deductibility.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether an amount claimed as an expenditure was laid out or expanded wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business has to be decided on the facts and in the light of the circumstances in each case. The mere existence of an agreement between the assessee and its selling agents or payment of certain amounts as commission, assuming there was such payment, does not bind the Income-tax Officer to hold that the payment was made exclusively and wholly for the purpose of the assessees business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Swadeshi Cotton Mills, deductibility under S.37 decided on facts; ITO not bound by agreement if sham.

holdings.text: Tribunal did not misconstrue documents; discrepancy exists as selling agency agreement assumes firm already in existence on March 26, 1962, but partnership deed shows existence from April 13, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad is not right in his contention that there is no discrepancy between the, agreement dated March 26, 1962 and the partnership deed dated April 13, 1962. The selling agency agreement proceeds on the basis that the partnership is already in existence. The assessee could have entered into an agreement only with an existing firm.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of documents shows firm not in existence on agreement date; resolves petitioner's claim of misconstruction.

holdings.text: Tribunal did not ignore oral evidence but rightly declined reliance due to surrounding circumstances; open to reject evidence not credible on facts.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Tribunal has not elaborately discussed the oral evidence. But it is not correct to say that the oral evidence has been ignored. In paragraph 6 of the Tribunals order, it notices the reliance placed by the assessee on the oral evidence. But it declined to place any reliance on the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal noticed evidence but found unpersuasive given facts like family ties, no infrastructure; AAC's acceptance ipse dixit.

holdings.text: Tribunal's findings that selling agency was sham/make-believe not perverse or unsupported; prima facie findings of fact.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie all these are findings of fact. Mr. M. C. Setalvad, appearing for the assessee challenged the findings reached by the Tribunal on two grounds viz. (1) that the Tribunal misconstrued or misunderstood the two documents viz. the selling agency agreement dated March 26, 1962 and the partnership deed dated April 13, 1962 and (2) the Tribunal ignored the oral evidence and the same has vitiated its conclusions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Findings based on documents, family relations, lack of infrastructure/experience; distinguished cases like Dhirajlal where irrelevant material used.

holdings.text: Tax avoidance by device permissible unless it camouflages assessee's income as another's; here Tribunal found latter, upheld.

anchor.surface_text: Avoidance of tax liability by so arranging commercial affairs that charge of tax is distributed is not prohibited. A tax payer may resort to a device to divert the income before it accrues or arises to him. Effectiveness of the device depends not upon considerations of morality but on the operation of the Income-tax Act. But ... if it is made to appear that the income which belonged to the assessee had been earned by some other person, that income may be brought to tax in the hands of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per A. Raman Co.; applies to facts where Tribunal found manifestation of assessee firm.

precedents.citation: Dhirajlal Girdharilal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bom- bay 1

anchor.surface_text: In Dhirajlal Girdharilal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bom- bay 1  this Court ruled that when a court of fact acts on material, partly relevant and partly irrelevant, it is impossible to say to what extent the mind of the court was affected by the irrelevant material used by it in arriving at its finding. Such a finding is vitiated because of the use of inadmissible material and thereby an issue of law arises.

precedents.case_name: Dhirajlal Girdharilal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: when a court of fact acts on material, partly relevant and partly irrelevant, it is impossible to say to what extent the mind of the court was affected by the irrelevant material used by it in arriving at its finding. Such a finding is vitiated because of the use of inadmissible material and thereby an issue of law arises

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal-II v. Rajasthan Mines Ltd., 2

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal-II v. Rajasthan Mines Ltd., 2  this Court held that it is open to the parties to challenge a conclusion of fact drawn by the Tribunal on the ground that it is not supported by any legal evidence or that the impugned conclusion drawn from the relevant facts is not rationally possible.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal-II v. Rajasthan Mines Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: it is open to the parties to challenge a conclusion of fact drawn by the Tribunal on the ground that it is not supported by any legal evidence or that the impugned conclusion drawn from the relevant facts is not rationally possible

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Gujarat v. A. Raman Co. 1

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax, Gujarat v. A. Raman Co. 1  this Court restated the well accepted proposition that the law does not oblige a trader to make the maximum profit that he can out of his trading transactions.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Gujarat v. A. Raman & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: law does not oblige a trader to make the maximum profit; avoidance of tax liability by arranging commercial affairs not prohibited; but if device makes it appear income earned by other person, may be taxed in assessee's hands

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab v. Indian Woollen Textile Mills 2

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab v. Indian Woollen Textile Mills 2  . Therein this Court observed that in that case the Tribunal assumed the only fact on which its. conclusion was founded and had ignored other relevant matters on which A.A.C. had relied in support of its conclusion.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab v. Indian Woollen Textile Mills
precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunal assumed only one fact and ignored other relevant matters, thus misdirected itself in law

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax West Bengal II v. Durga Prasad More 3

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax West Bengal II v. Durga Prasad More 3 . We fail to see how this decision can lend any assistance to the appellants case. In that case this Court reversing the decision of the High Court held that it could not be said that the finding of the Tribunal as to the unreality of the trust put forward was not based on evidence or was otherwise vitiated.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal II v. Durga Prasad More
precedents.cited_proposition: finding of Tribunal as to unreality of trust not vitiated if based on evidence

precedents.citation: Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. 4

anchor.surface_text: Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P.  4  The question whether an amount claimed as an expenditure was laid out or expanded wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business has to be decided on the facts and in the light of the circumstances in each case.

precedents.case_name: Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: whether amount claimed as expenditure laid out wholly and exclusively for business decided on facts of each case; mere agreement does not bind ITO

The assessee is a registered firm of three partners, Madanlal Bagaria, Bajranglal Bagaria and Sohanlal Bagaria, each having a 1/3rd share in the partnership.
In the result this appeal fails and the same is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, we are of opinion that the Tribunal was justified in not stating a case for the opinion of the High Court under s. 256 (1) of the Act and the High Court was justified in not calling for a statement of case under sub-s. (2) of s. 256.
In the result this appeal fails and the same is dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding explains scrutiny required for s.37 deduction beyond mere agreement, addressing the core issue of deductibility.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether an amount claimed as an expenditure was laid out or expanded wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business has to be decided on the facts and in the light of the circumstances in each case. The mere existence of an agreement between the assessee and its selling agents or payment of certain amounts as commission, assuming there was such payment, does not bind the Income-tax Officer to hold that the payment was made exclusively and wholly for the purpose of the assessees business.
In the result this appeal fails and the same is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad is not right in his contention that there is no discrepancy between the, agreement dated March 26, 1962 and the partnership deed dated April 13, 1962. The selling agency agreement proceeds on the basis that the partnership is already in existence. The assessee could have entered into an agreement only with an existing firm.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie all these are findings of fact. Mr. M. C. Setalvad, appearing for the assessee challenged the findings reached by the Tribunal on two grounds viz. (1) that the Tribunal misconstrued or misunderstood the two documents viz. the selling agency agreement dated March 26, 1962 and the partnership deed dated April 13, 1962 and (2) the Tribunal ignored the oral evidence and the same has vitiated its conclusions.
In the result this appeal fails and the same is dismissed with companyts.
